content.description:
“Certainly errors were committed; there were mistakes; there was a collective mistake. But there was also France, a certain idea of France, one that was just, generous, faithful to its traditions and its spirit. This France was never at Vichy.* Nor was it any longer—and for quite some time—in Paris. It was in the sands of Libya and everywhere that free French people fought. It was in London, embodied in General de Gaulle [leader of the Free French]. It was present, one and indivisible, in the hearts of those French people, those “Righteous among the Nations,” who, when the storm was darkest, risked their lives to save . . . three-quarters of the Jewish community living in France, thereby giving life to all that is best in France: to the humanistic values, the values of liberty, justice, and tolerance that are the foundation of the French identity and obligate us for the future.”
*A reference to the government set up to rule part of France after its defeat by Germany in 1940
Jacques Chirac, president of France, 1995 speech commemorating the roundup of French Jews in Paris in July 1942, during the Second World War
content.question: Which of the following would best support Chirac’s admission that the roundup of Jews commemorated during the speech constituted a “collective mistake”?

choices.label: The Jewish population in France was smaller than the Jewish populations of many eastern European countries that also were subject to roundups and executions.
French civil officials cooperated with German forces during the roundup.
Allied war planners were reluctant to commit resources to preventing German extermination policies toward Jews and other groups.
Jewish groups were able to form effective resistance units in some parts of Nazi-occupied Europe.

content.answer: French civil officials cooperated with German forces during the roundup.

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Explain how claims or evidence support, modify, or refute a source's argument.
